PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: W. B. Smith
Address: 214 S. Robinson Street, Regina, Saskatchewan
Birthplace: London, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? At Nelson's Farm, Broadview, Saskatchewan
Where had you been living before that? London, England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 adults, 2 children
How far was it to your nearest store? About 18 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Very seldom, from points had to be done
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, rolled oats, corn syrup, figs, yeast cakes, during war corn starch, which with potatoes were used in breadmaking according to regulations

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Household Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 95 lbs. each
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.94 (when my husband got it)
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? _______ What year? _______
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? _______
What other grain products did you use? Rolled Oats
Cornmeal? Yes, for Johnny
Whole Wheat? _______
Farina? _______
Other? _______

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? A homesteader would take him "grinding" or "mill" to any neighbour as a charge. Two sacks of "oat chop" thus ground had stood in the granary unused for want of pigs to feed it to. This became for us a godsend at one period. Having no flour in the home for bread making, the discovery of these two sacks was in the nature of a gold mine. We skimmed the mould off the top and enjoyed bread & porridge for weeks made with these two sacks & pig chop.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had cows, frogs, eggs, love, etc., at first. Later in 1917 we started to raise chickens daily for a quart.

In 1919, we had cows on farms, made our own butter, cream cheese.

Butter? Yes, from cows.

Eggs? Yes, from chickens.

Cheese? Yes, from cows.

Did you make butter? Yes, from cows.

Did you make cheese? Yes, from cows.

What kind of cheese? Cream Cheese.

(For butter making used hand churn.)

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We had no meat "supply."

How did you get fresh meat? We bought from local farmers.

How often did you get fresh meat? At very long intervals.

How did you preserve meat? In barrels, sealed with saltpetre.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so, what year was it organized? Probably about 1918.

Did you use game? Yes, from chickens.

What kind? Pigeons, partridges.

The winter of 1913-14, we lived on rabbits—also lived on woodchuck.

For how long? As long as they could be shot down in locality.

What part did fish play in the family diet? No part.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Day toast, dry tea, porridge with sugar
Dinner: Potatoes, beets, bread, eggs. Perhaps pancakes with corn syrup
Supper: Something similar. — 1912 - Husband 30 years, wife 32, brother-in-law 37 years. Winter & summer - But occasional changes of vegetables such as carrots and turnips; probably plums or figs might have figured - even baking powder dumplings with syrup - or a few currants.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? 1912

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I cannot remember the Christmas dinner I had prepared save that I made a traditional Christmas pudding & was horrified that oranges & a few other dainties were brought in from town to sober with pickling ingredients "in time". We had our dinner dinner on Boxing Day with brother-in-law, brother & wife, an old school friend & wife (whom I knew by name) with us, all about our ages 25 or less. What we ate I know not. We were at the friends on Christmas Day.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

From 1912 to 1914 yes often. My husband & brother worked from dawn to dusk on potatoes, bread, syrup, prunes & eggs, with which I put all possible effort to render palatable. One special occasion I myself was reduced to asking my husband if he could take a lift on a passing haywaggon to get perhaps some butter & eggs from my brother's - they did have some cows - for as I told him "I was starving." My sister-in-law lovingly rode over with a basin & butter which was the means of giving us a much needed meal.
16. Sharpness of observation. In the story "The Man Who Was Almost Born," what does the character Mr. Smith notice about his son?

17. Give a typical day's meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can find in the novel. Tell who prepared each meal.

Breakfast: Toast, coffee, bread, eggs, pancakes

Dinner: Potatoes, beans, bread, eggs, pancakes

Supper: Gravy, cornbread, beans, eggs, pancakes

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? Give details.

19. Have you ever refused to accept an invitation? Give details.

From 1912-5-1914 I often worked from dawn to dark on potatoes, bread, and parsnip taffy, which I paid for. It was hard work, but I enjoyed it.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Soft honeyed cakes compared with English fruit cakes. Fruit pies made in shallow pie plates with very thin crusts. Parts of beef being boiled, otherwise "boiled pink & silver." "Silverside" boiled beef of London tables. It appeared more than "offal" should not be made use of for meals, being despised; also sweet was made use of for meals, being despised; also sweet was used by poor people for whereas a Londoner regarded his food as a delicacy to English menus. Fruit cake was a whole-come addition to English menus. Fruit cake was a whole-come addition to English menus. Fruit cake was a whole-come addition to English menus. Fruit cake was a whole-come addition to English menus. Fruit cake was a whole-come addition to English menus. Fruit cake was a whole-come addition to English menus.

21. Than did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

While on the farm we retained the simple style of food evident in my replies above said. Since 1930 when we left the farm for good I have naturally fallen into the changed form of society, marketing and to a degree preparation of foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

As I never was in a position to "shop" at all from 1912 to 1920 I rarely have nothing to record. But I might mention that during my husband's home-keeping days (1908-12) he spent a winter in the shack, holding down his residence obligation while his brother was away earning, & tried for weeks on end on nothing but rolled oats, brown sugar & milk. It was a long while ere I could tempt him with porridge, which I ate heartily for special benefit of our children as they came along. After weaning the little ones were treated on cocoa made with plenty of condensed milk (Mother) and porridge.

Another fond memory of food I often laugh at was the occasion of a "Working Bee" a few days after arriving at Mulvick Farm. There were about 6
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest form as compared with today.

Step by step, and color coordinated with English food.

Very thin... ornate (Parts of beef being formed into various London tables. It was made of silver "Silverware" or plated metal)
